nodes.bodyText:
and if we were able to insert a partial stack first and then the rest?
This should have worked fine up to now.

resultStack is the remainder already for the partial insert, which gets re-used in the loop till its empty or the loop failed. So when its empty we can fit the whole. But can probably simplify this a lot later.
The issue with this was that the return value lost information,  doing a partial insert combined with true/false return either leads to some information loss, or to having to modify the stack parameters size and hoping there is followup logic which is really hacky. So this is now all or nothing
This is flawed logic. There are inventories from which you can't extract and not insert.
you're saying there are inventories which take a not-empty stack into insert and then return an empty stack without beeing able to insert it?
hm but I think if insert with simulate works then insert without simulate should work aswell?

You are violating the IITemHandler contract here!
Always simulate first before performing any operation
where do I find that IITemHandler contract? in the documentation I only see that input stacks are not to be modified, thats all

It is not really a contract.
It is the general rule that was setup when they where defined:
First test if you actually can modify the inventory
Then actually the modification when you are happy with it.
ah I see, so for that we always want to do extract simulate -> insert simulate -> extract real -> insert real?
btw I saw that forge(or maybe vanilla?) does insert simulate -> set stack for inventories

Both work really.
Important is that you do a simulate first.
Set stack just overrides.
Forge does it in vanilla cause insert simulate -> set stack basically is the same.

Personally I would create something like an Inventory interaction handler
Which records somehow the interactions thgat you want to do.
THen returns the simulated results, and allows you to tell it to commit the change.
ye that would be nice to have, kinda like DB transactions

Yes exactly.
Something that has the exact same signatures as IItemHandler (Except maybe the simulate flag) or something.
Shouldn't we able to code this in a utility function somehow?
ye should be doable, although I'd leave that for the rework, since this was just supposed to be bugfixes
